docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant reviews two-volume Cambridge World History of Food; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A VENERABLE academic rivalry has found its way to the kitchen -- to the kitchen bookshelf, that is. For sheer heft, the Cambridge World History of Food, with 2,152 pages in two volumes, wins in a knockout over the Oxford Companion to Food, at 892 pages. Not that the Oxford book (Oxford University Press, 1999, $60), by Alan Davidson, is light work for the intellect. It's an eminently useful reference tool compiled alphabetically. But the Cambridge entry, likewise a scholarly work (Cambridge University Press, $150), edited by Kenneth F. Kiple and Kriemhild Conee Ornelas and published in November, peppers its research with the opinions of its contributors, most of whom are associated with universities.

headline.main: Tax Junk Food to Fight Obesity

docs.abstract: Valeria Vasilevski letter on Dec 26 article and others in series on fat epidemic calls for special tax on foods containing more than prescribed percentage of daily minimal fat intake
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Contemplating the series on the fat epidemic, including ''Rampant Obesity, a Debilitating Reality for the Urban Poor'' (Dec. 26) and statistics showing the large percentage of overweight Americans, I suggest that fat be treated in the same way as tobacco and be taxed. There is plenty of precedent. Alcohol is judged sinful so we created a ''sin tax.'' Cigarettes are deemed unhealthy so we created a tobacco tax. Isn't it sensible then to pass a ''fat tax?''

headline.main: Many Americans Fed Up With Diet Advice

docs.abstract: Seventy percent of adult respondents in survey led by Ruth E Patterson say Americans are obsessed with subject of dietary fat and agree that government should not tell people what to eat; 25 percent find eating low-fat foods less enjoyable; 40 percent are tired of hearing about what foods they should or should not eat; men ages 18 to 35, the elderly and poorer people especially reject dietary admonitions (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: As many Americans make New Year's resolutions focusing on weight loss and healthier eating habits, a new study released today highlights a growing tendency to disregard expert dietary advice. In a random survey of 1,750 adults, 70 percent maintained that Americans were obsessed with the subject of fat in their diets and agreed that the government should not tell people what to eat.

headline.main: Tax Junk Food to Fight Obesity

docs.abstract: Susan M Price letter on Dec 26 article cites low-cost ways to control obesity with exercise and balanced eating
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: While I agree that obesity is a problem, anyone who has money to eat fast food every day can not be that poor (''Rampant Obesity''). As far as activity, walking is free. Weights can be made by using canned foods or filling jugs with water. Warm ups and stretches can be done while watching television. Even reading or drawing can occupy time and prevent a boredom snack raid.
